content.description:
Follow bolts traversing right on large holds. Save some juice to power through the crux sequence pulling out to the vertical face from the overhang.

Farthest right route on the lower wall.
3 bolts

Short, powerful route with a reachy move 2/3 up.

On the far, lower left side of Milkman Wall.
Bolts

Starts on the overhang under the arete. A few powerful moves and it's over.

4 bolts

An excellent companion route to Horrors that offers arguably better face climbing.  This is a fairly serious lead and would be an incredible on-sight for someone with the sufficient mental and physical strength.  
  
 The climbing is typical Milkman wall stuff - slightly over-hanging with some long reaches between good holds. 
 Start with hard moves off the deck to a bolt at about 15' (don't fall getting to it).  From the bolt, some more steep crimping takes you slightly left to a jug with good feet.  This is the best rest and allows you to place good gear from a nice stance.  Move up and right through a tough overlap to the Horrors Cave and then back left to a decent rest and another opportunity for gear.  You probably want to double up on the pro at this point since this is all you get.  The next few moves getting established on the head wall are pumpy but all there.  Keep a cool head and continue up on small but positive crimps -  the climbing eases off as you get higher but the run-out will keep your attention

The route starts just right of Mr. O'Clock (about 10' left of Horrors)
a single rack to 2" is plenty.

Quality climbing on steep rock. Crux hits you at bolt 3.

Directly to the right of Jugs not Drugs (5.8) and left of a dead tree on the ledge.
3 quickdraws. The anchor is 2 bolts each with a segment of chain.

Climb past two bolts to a small cave in the middle of the wall.  Move up right into a crack to finish.

2 bolts, standard rack.

Follow huge jugs on flakes up to a more technical finish.

Farthest left route.
5 Bolts

climbs.name: Mr. Crabbe
climbs.fa: Royal Robbins (I think)....not sure who got the FFA

content.description:
Yet another classic Milkman Wall route.  This climb takes the rising, rightward crack line starting at the layback feature at the bottom of Tourist Delight. 
 Climb easily up on juggy flakes, passing Mr. O'Clock until you merge into the crux of El Indio.  Follow the right trendign crack into the Horrors cave and finish as for that route.

Starts immediately after the 3rd class scramble
Single rack from BD .3 to 2, with doubles of .4, .5, .75

This route follows obvious right-facing flakes up to a stance at a shelf.  A small cam protects the pull over the bulge and into the shallow left-facing corner system, then a traverse left on cool jugs leads to a mantel and the chains.

Directly above the flat rock on the left side of the Horrors of Ivan zone.  This is the second route left of HoI, identified by the right facing flakes at the start.
C3s, nuts or other small gear for the bottom and left-facing corner, and a bigger piece in the .5 camalot range to protect the finish.

Starts with some fun layback moves. Â Focus on good foot placement going up the corner, and look for a good hold up to the left near the anchor.

Standard Rack (SR)

A worthy linkup. Start by clipping the first bolt of "The Pass", then move up and left clipping a couple of bolts on the way into the "Horrors of Ivan" cave. Keep traversing left along the horizontal until you can move upwards, finishing on "Mr. O'clock".  
 PUMPY

left of "... Milkman", starting on "The Pass"
3 protection bolts, cams to 2", bolted anchor

While considerably more overhanging than your average 5.8, a series of excellent flakes provide great holds and protection.  The final mantel on a great jug will make you smile.

Some medium to large nuts and a single set of cams up to 3 inches should be fine.  A 3.5 camalot can be used at the finish if you want to sew it up.

Start past a low bolt and climb up and past a fixed pin to your left. Climb past another bolt into the crux with a tiny crack that will take a Green C3, pull over the arete and up the slab.

After the scramble to the Milkman area, right above the big half buried section of granite on the ledge.
2 bolts and gear.

This wall, part of the Sugarloaf, Brunser, and Xodus group of crags, only contains  six or seven routes, but they were  some of Squamish's 1980's testpieces.  One exception is the easier route The World's Toughest Milkman.
